Arrange a translator via the phone translating service

questions:
You are a junior doctor assessing a 35-year-old lady in the Emergency Department. She is a Latvian immigrant and speaks no English. She has brought her 6-year-old son with her and he speaks some English. From your initial assessment you feel that her abdominal pain poses a requires admission and further investigation. There are no Latvian speaking translators available at your hospital.

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
Effective communication is essential to the consent process, both in terms of providing patients with sufficient information to ensure consent is valid and making sure that patients are not coerced into consenting to treatment. In some circumstances, it will not be possible to wait for an interpreter without risking serious harm to the patient and the priority will be providing treatment to prevent such harm.

In this scenario, arranging an interpreter either via telephone translating service or in person is the best option. Allowing the boy to do so is not appropriate - information may become lost in translation. From the stem we understand this lady requires emergency treatment hence waiting for a translator is not appropriate because this could put her at risk of serious harm. Reading her previous notes may help us to understand her past medical history which is always useful in the meantime.

title: Consent
body:
There are 3 types of consent:

1. Informed
2. Expressed
3. Implied

Consent forms used in UK NHS
Consent Form 1For competent adults who are able to consent for themselves where consciousness may be impaired (e.g. GA)
Consent Form 2For an adult consenting on behalf of a child where consciousness is impaired
Consent Form 3For an adult or child where consciousness is not impaired
Consent Form 4For adults who lack capacity to provide informed consent

Capacity
Key points include:
1. Understand and retain information
2. Patient believes the information to be true
3. Patient is able to weigh the information to make a decision
All patients must be assumed to have capacity

Consent in minors
Young children and older children who are not Gillick competent cannot consent for themselves. In British law the patient's biological mother can always provide consent. The childs father can consent if the parents are married (and the father is the biological father), or if the father is named on the birth certificate (irrespective of marital status). If parents are not married and the father is not named on the birth certificate then the father cannot consent.

Decline the gift, explaining your reasons
Thank him for the kind gesture

questions:
You are a F2 in the Respiratory ward. A 65-year-old patient that you have been caring for is being discharged today. He is thankful for all the help you and the staff have given him during his admission and he gives you a box of chocolates.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
It is not uncommon for patients to show their gratitude by buying gifts for members of staff that have been involved in their care. As a general rule, something that is small and can be shared amongst the staff such as a box of chocolates is acceptable. Money, on the other hand, is unacceptable. The GMC guidelines state that 'You must not ask for or accept from patients, colleagues or others any inducement, gift or hospitality that may affect or be seen to affect the way you prescribe for, treat or refer patients or commission services for patients.'

The gift is of small monetary value and can be easily shared amongst the ward staff.
Therefore, you should thank the patient, accept the gift and share it with the team (options C, F and G).

Keeping the gift for yourself or giving it to your partner may be seen as being selfish (option E). Suggesting to the patient that they should contribute something to the ward may put them in a difficult position (option D). Making a swift exit when someone has offered you a gift is rude (option H). Declining the gift (option B) may affect the doctor-patient relationship and offend the patient, particularly as this is a low monetary item.

There is no need to place such a gift on a register (option A)

See the GMC guidelines on accepting gifts here: http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/21161.asp

questions:
You are the F2 on a paediatrics ward. The single parent of a patient on the ward who is very unwell has asked for your mobile phone number. He/she says that she needs it to keep up to date with her child whilst she is at work.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
Whilst there is no specific guidance about this given by the General Medical Council, this matter relates to professionalism. It is not appropriate to give your personal information to either a patient or their family members. Handing over the information for another member of staff is even less professional. The most appropriate options are to give the ward phone number since this is well within hospital policy or to take the number of the family member.

Giving the wrong phone number is breach of trust and is obviously inappropriate.

Email is not generally considered a secure line of communication and is inappropriate in this situation.

options: Explain to her that this is not her decision
Ask her daughter if she is in agreement with her mother
Reassure her that you will modify the documentation to recommend ITU admission if required
Ask about her understanding of ITU admission and reasoning behind her request

Provide her with the contact details of the Patient Advice and Liaison Service (PALS)
Advise her to seek out a professional second opinion on the matter
Explain the rationale behind the medical team's recommendation
Reassure her that a ward-based ceiling of care does not mean you will stop her current treatment

questions:
You review an 87-year-old woman admitted with pneumonia on the post-take medical ward round. She is currently medically stable receiving intravenous antibiotics and fluids. Your consultant discusses ceilings of care with her and her daughter, and recommends a ward-based ceiling of care. She is deemed to have mental capacity regarding the topic and does not express any disagreement.

Later that day you are called over to her bedside where she tells you that she would want full medical escalation, including admission to the Intensive Treatment Unit (ITU), in the case of her deterioration.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This example is a common occurrence in medical practice and doctors should be confident about their professional role in the dilemma.

The General Medical Council (GMC) are clear that when deemed to have capacity, the patient should always be involved in decisions about their end-of-life care, including ceilings of care. Ultimately, the doctor has the final say in what treatment they offer, but the patient should always be consulted for their views and have the rationale explained to them. On the flip side, patients have the right to refuse treatment if they so wish.

Disagreements often arise in the context of patients requesting treatment that doctors do not feel is in their best interests. The GMC is clear that in these cases, doctors should explore their reasons for requesting it, their understanding of what it would involve, and their expectations about the likely outcome. Often patients will have misconceptions and providing them with the appropriate information can get everyone on the same side.

For this reason D, H and I are the correct answers as they explore the patient's wishes, clarify with the patient what is meant by 'ward-based ceiling of care' and provide the rationale behind the consultant's recommendation.

While option A is not technically incorrect, it does nothing to solve the situation and can escalate tensions. It is important to involve the patient's loved ones (with their permission), but in this case, the patient is deemed to have capacity and there are better options than asking the daughter as in option B.

Option C is inappropriate because your consultant will have had a reason for their recommendation and you should not override their decision without consulting them. Option E does not seek to gather the patient's reasoning and unnecessarily inflames the situation.

In this case, it is premature to refer the patient to PALS as in option F. Similarly, the patient does have a right to seek a second opinion but there are simpler measures that may resolve the situation before resorting to option G.

Providing you understand the consultant's reasoning for recommending a ward-based ceiling of care, you should not ask them to re-review the decision until you have gathered more information from the patient and attempted to resolve the situation yourself. Option J is not an appropriate first step.

title: GMC: Treatment and care towards the end of life - Working with the principles and decision-making models
body:
There's an old aphorism in medicine sometimes attributed to Hippocrates: 'c'ure sometimes, treat often, comfort always'. This reminds us to think about goals of care. The end of life is a time when it is important to think ethically and communicate effectively about these goals.

Recognition that a patient is entering the end of life is the first step is determining the goals of care. We are often too slow to see the signs that death is near, and too slow to think that our interventions need to change in order to reflect this. Just because a patient cannot be cured does not mean they should not be treated or comforted.

Good palliative care at the end of life can make the difference between an agonising and emotionally traumatic death or one in comfort, quiet and relative dignity. Good clinical medicine and good ethical reasoning are needed to make sure this happens.

Key principles

The GMC lists key principles which should control decision-making at the end of life.

Equalities and human rights. Those at the end of life are owed the same quality of care as all patients, including with regard to dignity and confidentiality.

Presumption in favour of prolonging life. Any decision about potentially life-prolonging treatment should not be motivated by a desire to bring about a patient's death. There is also a general presumption to take all reasonable steps which can prolong life, though, depending on patient's wishes and doctors' clinical judgement, it may be considered appropriate to refrain from providing or withdraw a potentially life-prolonging intervention.

Presumption of capacity. The usual assumption that all adults have capacity until it has been shown they lack it applies to patients at the end of life.

Maximising capacity to make decisions. Capacity should be assessed for each relevant decision, and steps should be taken to support patients in doing so.

Overall benefit. If a patient lacks capacity, a decision in their overall benefit should be made.

A decision-making model for patients with capacity
  • Assess the patient's condition, understanding and views
  • Use your experience and clinical judgment to identify investigations and treatments clinically appropriate and likely to result in overall benefit for the patient. Explain these options, laying out their potential burdens, risks and benefits
  • Allow the patient to accept or refuse any of these options

What if a patient with capacity requests something clinically inappropriate?

Inquire into why the patient is making such a request, and clarify potential misunderstandings. If the patient maintains their clinically inappropriate request you are not obliged to fulfil it. You should explain why you do not think it is appropriate and allow the patient to exercise their right to a second opinion should they wish to do so.

A decision-making model for adults who lack capacity

There are some additional measure to take for adults who lack capacity:
  • Clearly identify which clinical decisions need to be made
  • Check if the patient has a legally binding advance decision
  • Find out if the patient has a legal proxy (NB: not all proxies are permitted to make medical decisions)
  • Take responsibility for deciding which treatment will provide overall benefit to the patient if there is no legal proxy, making sure to consult those close to the patient when doing so

When this stage is reached, the model for making a clinical decision is as follows:
  • Along with the patient's carer, assess the patient's condition, understanding and views
  • Along with evidence of the patient's views, use your experience and clinical judgement to identify investigations and treatments clinically appropriate and likely to result in overall benefit for the patient
  • If there is evidence of an advance decision, judge whether it is legally binding and/or applicable to the current circumstances
  • If it is, follow it. If it is not, include it as evidence in your assessment of a patient's wishes
  • If the patient has a legal proxy for clinical decisions, explain to them the different options along with their potential risks, benefits and burdens. Support the proxy's decision-making but do not pressurise it
  • If a proxy does not have legal power over clinical decisions their views should be considered, along with those of the rest of the healthcare team
  • In England and Wales, if there is no proxy or forthcoming other person to assist in the process, arrange for an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate to do so

What if there is disagreement between the proxy the medical team?

If the patient has a proxy to make clinical decisions and there is disagreement between the proxy and the medical team about what clinical decisions should be made steps should be taken to resolve the matter informally, for example by holding a case meeting, getting a second opinion, engaging in further discussion.

If all this fails, seek legal advice.

How do I make a decision in overall benefit?

Making a decision which is in the patient's overall benefit requires you to think both about clinically and ethically. It's not just a question of asking 'will this intervention work'? You also must ask: 'is it the right thing for this patient under these circumstances?'

What might be routine in other circumstances might be inappropriate if a patient is in extremis, for example because the intervention has an unreasonably small prospect of changing management and benefiting the patient. Fluid resuscitation might be basic protocol in other cases, but if a patient is lying on their death bed, it is unclear that they will derive a benefit from intravenous cannulation and a fluid bolus (subcutaneous fluids, however, might be appropriate).

Some questions to ask:
  • What is the aim of this procedure under these circumstances?
  • Does this procedure benefit the patient?
  • Is this aim appropriate to the goals of care?
  • Are these goals better served by other interventions?

NB: these questions are all about whether the intervention is worthwhile, not whether prolonging life of a given patient is worthwhile. The decision to refrain from intervening or withdrawing an intervention is best made on the basis of the proportionality of the intervention itself and not based on a judgement upon the value of the life it aims to sustain.

Putting this in to practice: DNACPR

Decisions to not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation illustrate the principles laid out in this guidance. When broaching this subject with patients/proxies it is important to communicate clearly the potential risks, benefits and harms. You need to assess the patient's clinical condition carefully as well as their own views. Then you need to lay before them the different options explaining the relevant risks etc. If you are satisfied that the patient understands this but still wishes to be resuscitated, it is important to explore this further. However, ultimately, the patient's wish cannot compel you to engage in CPR if, in your considered professional judgement, it is not appropriate.

Note, however, that a DNACPR order is not a licence for neglect or an excuse to stop all treatment. A patient may 'be DNACPR' but intravenous antibiotics might still be appropriate for them, for example. A DNACPR is only one clinical decision: the decisions that CPR would be inappropriate. It says nothing about other ceilings of care.

General pointers

Good communication'at a time of life which is fraught with emotion and stress poor communication and misunderstanding can only hinder care.

Plan ahead'failing to think about the end of life can leave patients and medical teams unprepared. Don't be blindsided by a deteriorating patient. Keep an eye out for the signs of decline and initiate the important discussions with the patient, relatives and colleagues.

Uncertainty'there is a lot of uncertainty around death. Help relatives deal with this by explaining what their relative is experiencing and what your plan is.

Review decisions'sometimes, a patient's condition will change unexpectedly. Be ready to reconsider previous decisions in light of this.

Know the law'be familiar with the laws relevant to your jurisdiction concerning capacity, advanced decisions etc.

Think ethically'just like it is important to reason from basic principles to conclusions in clinical medicine, so it is important to reason ethically through difficult decisions.

questions: You are a ST1 doctor working on the palliative care ward. A patient who has terminal cancer asks you to give him an overdose of medication to 'end the pain once and for all'. You explain to them that this is illegal in the United Kingdom. What is the most appropriate next step?
notes:
Exploring why the patient feels that way is the most appropriate option as it will help identify if the patient has depression, or whether there is anything you can do to help manage them. Discussing 'advanced directives' is the next most appropriate step as it will identify management options available to the patient. Suggesting the patient talk to their next of kin may be helping in providing them with further support, although it does not address the immediate issue of euthanasia.

It is not appropriate to refer the patient to the psychiatry team as they do not necessarily have mental health problems. The least appropriate option is to inform the patient's next of kin as this breaks confidentiality.

General Medical Council (2010) Treatment and care towards the end of life: good practice in decision making

options: Explain that you do not feel comfortable performing the examination without a chaperone
Explore why the patient has declined a chaperone and explain why one has been offered
Make the patient an appointment for the afternoon with a GP of the same sex
Perform the examination and document that a chaperone was declined
Perform the examination with the mother acting as chaperone and document her name in the notes
questions:
You are working in general practice. Your next patient is a patient of the opposite sex who has had two recent episodes of concerning rectal bleeding and requires a digital rectal examination. The patient is not currently bleeding and their observations are all stable.

You wish to perform the examination with a chaperone present as you know that the patient has previously raised complaints about examinations by other opposite-sex GPs. However, the patient declines a chaperone but adds that, if you really want someone else in the room, their mother is in the waiting room and will be able to act as a chaperone.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
The GMC has produced guidance on 'Intimate Examinations and Chaperones' (2013). A chaperone should be offered for all intimate examinations. If a patient declines, it is appropriate to document this and continue the examination, so long as the doctor is comfortable examining the patient without a chaperone. If the doctor wishes a chaperone to be present, the doctor does not have to go ahead with the examination unless postponing the examination would cause adverse consequences. The doctor can discuss with the patient why they would like a chaperone and, if the patient still declines, arrange for the patient to be examined by another doctor. In this case, the first most appropriate answer is to explore why the patient has declined a chaperone and explain why one has been offered.

If, after this conversation, the issue has not been resolved, the GP may need to explain that you do not feel comfortable performing the examination without a chaperone. At this point, the patient may agree to a chaperone being present. If not, it may be appropriate to make alternative arrangements depending on clinical urgency. It is important to reach a decision that both the doctor and patient feel comfortable with, although ultimately patient safety will be the most important factor in decision making.

Make the patient an appointment for the afternoon with a GP of the same sex is the next most appropriate option if the issue cannot be resolved. An appointment should not be rescheduled if there is clinical urgency and it may affect outcomes. However, given the patient is stable - albeit with a symptom that does require urgent investigation - rescheduling the examination until the afternoon will not affect outcomes.

Perform the examination and document that a chaperone was declined is not ideal, as it is clear that you do not feel comfortable examining the patient without a chaperone. Whilst this examination is important and should be done as soon as possible, it is not so time-sensitive that alternative arrangements cannot be made. However, there will be times where, due to urgency, the patient's need to be examined and desire not to have a chaperone will trump the doctor's wish to have a chaperone. In these cases, it is very important to document that a chaperone has been offered and declined.

Perform the examination with the mother acting as chaperone, documenting her name in the notes is the least appropriate. Family members must not act as chaperones as they are not impartial observers. This option is even worse than not using a chaperone as essentially the examination is unchaperoned, you may open yourself to complaints from the patient and mother and you are setting false expectations that family members can be used as chaperones which may affect further interactions that this family has with healthcare professionals.

title: GMC: Intimate examinations and chaperones
body:
The GMC has produced extensive guidance on how to appropriately perform intimate examinations and the role of chaperones in this. The guidance covers what constitutes an intimate examination, how a doctor should conduct such an examination and how chaperones should be involved in the process.

Intimate examinations:
  • Essentially this is anything the patient would consider intimate or intrusive
  • This will most commonly be examinations of the rectum, genitalia and breasts
  • This definition can be different for any patient and you should think about whether the patient would consider what you are doing intimate

Performing the examination:
  • As with any procedure, you should seek informed consent from the patient to carry out the examination
  • This involves explaining what you will do and why and how exposed they will be
  • You should make sure they are happy to proceed and ensure they have had all their questions answered
  • In addition you should explain that you will stop the examination at any point if asked to by the patient
  • During the examination it is good practice to only talk if it is relevant to the examination

Chaperones:
  • A chaperone is an impartial person who is present during the examination to both offer support to the patient and act as an observer to ensure the examination is carried out in a professional manner
  • They should be a healthcare worker who has no relation to the patient or doctor. Patients may also wish to have family members present for support but they cannot be relied upon as chaperones as they are not impartial
  • The full name and role of the chaperone should be documented in the medical records with the examination findings
  • In the event of the patient making any allegations against the doctor with regards to the examination, the chaperone can be called on as a witness
  • The chaperone should also be able to safely announce whether they feel any behaviours are inappropriate during the examination
  • It is not mandatory to have a chaperone and many patients may wish to be examined without another individual present. In these cases, the offer and refusal should be documented in the medical records
  • A doctor should not feel pressured to perform an examination without a chaperone if they do not wish. However, they should ensure the patient is referred to a colleague who is comfortable doing so and that they would not wait unnecessarily for treatment because of this

Examples

You are a male GP and are seeing a female Muslim patient who wears a Hijab due to a chronic cough. You need to perform a respiratory examination
  • Although you may not normally consider listening to the chest to be an intimate examination, you must be sensitive to other people's cultures and beliefs and in this case it is reasonable to assume the patient may wish for a chaperone to be present if she is to have her chest exposed for the examination
  • A chaperone should be offered and then if requested their full name and role documented in the medical records

A 63-year-old man attends his GP due to problems passing urine. His GP wishes to perform a prostate examination. The patient agrees but does not want a chaperone present
  • The offer and refusal of a chaperone should be documented in the medical records but this should not prevent the doctor performing the examination
  • If the doctor is comfortable to do so then they may perform the examination, if not they must refer to a colleague to do so

A 19-year-old female attends her GP with urethral discharge. The male GP wishes to perform a vaginal exam and take swabs but he feels she has been very inappropriately sexual with him during the consultation and she is refusing to allow a chaperone to be present for the examination
  • You should feel under no obligations to perform any procedure or examination you are not comfortable doing
  • The most reasonable solution here would be to ask if a colleague could perform the examination on your behalf provided they are happy to do so without a chaperone
  • A patient should never be forced to have a chaperone present for an examination if they do not wish although it is not unreasonable to further explain the reasons for offering a chaperone in these situations beyond simply offering one
  • A patient's care should not be delayed so ideally a colleague should be able to perform this examination within the immediate future or the patient should be referred on to another service which may be able to examine her

options: Ask the nurse some questions about the patient to decide whether or not to prescribe the tramadol
Prescribe the tramadol, this nurse sounds like she knows what she is talking about
Tell her you are too busy for this, she will have to wait until the day team comes in
Tell her once you are done dealing with an unwell patient you will come to assess her patient

questions:
You are doing a busy on-call shift. At the moment, you are attending to an unwell patient. One of the nurses bleeps you and asks you to prescribe some tramadol for one of her patients. The ward she is calling from is on the other end of the hospital from where you are right now. Your hospital has an electronic prescribing system. The nurse says that you do not need to see the patient, and you can just prescribe it from where you are.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
'If you prescribe at the recommendation of a nurse or other healthcare professional who does not have prescribing rights, you must be satisfied that the prescription is appropriate for the patient concerned and that the professional is competent to have recommended the treatment.'

Option D is the most appropriate, as you should be sure you are prescribing the right medication for the right patient. You should review the patient yourself, review the indication for tramadol, review the medications the patient is already on, and whether there are any contraindications for the prescription. As the prescriber, you are responsible for the prescription.

Option A is less appropriate, as it does not involve you physically reviewing the patient. However, you might be able to gain sufficient information from the nurse to decide whether this prescription would be appropriate. You should still ideally review the patient's notes and assess the patient.

Option C is even less appropriate, as you are not even attempting to get more information, and you are assuming you will not be able to review the patient. As much as attending to an acutely unwell patient is of higher priority, a patient who is in severe pain will also be very high on a priority list, and you should try your best to attend to them next.

Option B is inappropriate. Even if the nurse is experienced and knows what she is talking about, ultimately, you are the responsible prescriber and need to ensure that you are correct in prescribing it.

Option E is the most inappropriate, as not only are you blindly following the nurse's recommendation, you are encouraging her to administer the drug without a documented prescription.

title: GMC: Prescribing and managing medicines and devices content
body:
Good Practice in Prescribing Medicines was published in 2008. A link is provided to the full guidance, below is only selected highlights:

Principles of prescribing
  • doctors with full registration may prescribe all medicines, but not those drugs in Schedule 1 of the Misuse of Drugs Regulations 2001
  • you should only prescribe drugs to meet identified needs of patients and never for your own convenience or simply because patients demand them
  • avoid treating yourself and those close to you

Keeping up to date and prescribing in patients' best interests
  • the guidelines make specific mention of the BNF, NICE and SIGN
  • you should inform the Committee on the Safety of Medicines of adverse reactions to medicines reported by your patients in accordance with the Yellow Card Scheme
  • if you prescribe at the recommendation of a nurse or other healthcare professional who does not have prescribing rights, you must be satisfied that the prescription is appropriate for the patient concerned and that the professional is competent to have recommended the treatment

Doctors' interests in pharmacies
  • you should ensure that your patients have access to information about your own and (where known) your employers' financial or commercial interests in any pharmacy they are likely to use

Prescribing controlled drugs for yourself or someone close to you
  • doctors should, wherever possible, avoid treating themselves or anyone with whom they have a close personal relationship and should be registered with a GP outside their family
  • you should not prescribe a controlled drug for yourself or someone close to you unless no other person with the legal right to prescribe is available to assess the patient's clinical condition and to prescribe without a delay which would put the patient's life or health at risk, or cause the patient unacceptable pain, and that treatment is immediately necessary to save life, avoid serious deterioration in the patient's health or alleviate otherwise uncontrollable pain

Remote prescribing via telephone, email, fax, video link or a website
  • this is supported in the guidelines with obvious caveats
  • if you are 'not providing continuing care for the patient', for example doing out-of-hours the guidelines recommend giving an explanation to the patient of the processes involved in remote consultations and giving your name and GMC number to the patient

options: Respect the consultant's opinion and prescribe thyroxine
Write a letter to the consultant asking for clarification as to why thyroxine is being prescribed
Write a letter to the consultant explaining that you are not happy to prescribe thyroxine
Advise the patient to sue the consultant
Refer the patient to an endocrinologist on the NHS for a second opinion
questions:
You are a GP registrar. The next patient has been seen at the surgery before complaining of being tired all the time. She brings in a letter from a private clinic asking you to prescribe thyroxine. In the letter the consultant explains that whilst the patient's TSH is normal the thyroxine level is at the lower end of the normal range and he feels that a trial of thyroxine is indicated to help speed up her metabolism.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Inappropriate requests for medication or treatment may occasionally be made by third parties.

The best response is to write to the consultant asking for clarification. It may be that it is a recognised/established treatment that they are requesting. This approach avoids making the mistake of presuming a treatment option is not valid simply because you have not heard of it.

Referring the patient to a NHS consultant would hopefully ensure they receive appropriate treatment but may not be necessary or desired by the patient.

The next best option is to write a letter explaining that you are not happy to prescribe thyroxine in this instance. From a patient's point of view, this doesn't move the situation forward and hence is ranked lower than getting a second opinion.

Simply accepting a treatment because a third party has recommended it is a poor option as it may potentially put the patient at risk - what if the thyroxine request was a typing error?

options: Give her the details of a domestic violence support group
Tell her that you have no alternative but to contact the police
Check her FBC and clotting
Draw a detailed diagram of her injuries + refer her for counselling
Phone the partner after the patient as left and warn him of further action if he doesn't stop
questions:
A 44-year-old woman present to the GP surgery for a blood pressure check. You notice she has multiple bruises on her arms. She tells you there have been 'some problems at home' but doesn't want the police involved.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Scenarios involving domestic violence can be difficult to deal with.

The people who are most likely to be able to offer practical advice are domestic violence support groups. They will have specific knowledge of housing and financial issues. A general counselling service is less able to provide this support and may imply to the women that you feel she is at fault. As she is reluctant for police involvement at this stage drawing a diagram of her injuries is less relevant although it is still good practice.

Checking her bloods is unlikely to be relevant - her bruises are likely to be a result of violence by her partner.

Unless you feared for the patient's life this is not a situation where you would break confidentiality. It is possible such action may put the woman at more risk of violence.

Phoning the partner directly is the worst option as this both breaks confidentiality and is likely to put the patient at risk of retribution.

options: Advise the children's school of the allegations
Advise the patient that if she does not seek support, she may lose care of her children
Advise the patient you cannot keep this information confidential
Contact local child protection services
Contact the council to arrange emergency housing for the family
Give the patient information on local domestic violence support groups
Encourage the patient to arrange relationship counselling
Make the patient an appointment with a senior for the following week to discuss these concerns in greater detail and make a plan
Reassure the patient that this information will be kept confidential but encourage her to seek support
Reassure the patient that this information will be kept confidential but make her an appointment with a senior for the following day
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in general practice. A woman attends your clinic with insomnia. You notice extensive bruising on her body and, when asked about this, she admits that her partner is frequently violent.

The woman has three school-aged children who are present. They appear relaxed, clean and well-kempt. She admits that her partner is sometimes aggressive towards the children and can threaten them with violence, however, he has only actually been physically violent towards them once, several months ago.

The patient tells you her husband has just left for a week-long business trip and begs you not to inform anyone of what she has disclosed as she plans to use this time to seek help anyway.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This scenario revolves around the disclosure of abuse from a patient who does not wish to take the disclosure further. In Good Medical Practice (2013), the GMC state that all patients have the right to a confidential medical service. GMC guidance states that 'doctors should usually abide by the wishes of an adult patient who refuses consent to information being shared, even if that leaves them, but nobody else, at risk of harm.' However, this does not apply in this scenario as it is not just the patient at risk but also her children. Regardless of the fact that the children appear relaxed and well looked after, it is clear from the brief that they have experienced abuse. Confidentiality can be waived if disclosing the information is justified in the public interest. This is the case in this scenario as children are at risk. This would also be the case if a vulnerable adult was at risk. It is, therefore, appropriate to inform relevant services. Contact local child protection services is thus one of the correct options.

Advise the patient you cannot keep this information confidential is correct. The GMC state clearly that, when disclosing information without consent, you should explain clearly to the involved parties why the information has been shared and how the information will be used.

The final correct option is give the patient information on local domestic violence support groups. The GMC state clearly that, when disclosing abuse, patients should be given access to information and support. The GMC also states that, when sharing information about abuse, the patient should be given access to groups that can provide independent advice and support.

Advise the children's school of the allegations is incorrect. Although the children's school will likely be involved in subsequent proceedings, involving them now is not a priority. Instead, child protection services will need to coordinate the response to this disclosure and ensure the children's welfare. Furthermore, as the school is not the appropriate agency to initially deal with these allegations, talking to the school without the patient's consent would be breaking confidentiality. As above, you are only allowed to disclose information without consent if it is in public interest. In these cases, the information is disclosed to the relevant agency and the patient must be advised of what information has been disclosed and to who.

Advise the patient that if she does not seek support, she may lose care of her children is likely to leave the patient, who is a victim in this scenario, feeling judged, guilty and afraid. As discussed above, you need to break confidentiality regardless of whether the patient chooses to seek support or not. Whilst it would be appropriate to explain why the patient needs help, including the element of risk to her children, this manner is blunt and may panic the patient and cause her to lose trust in those trying to help her. It is certainly far less appropriate than giving the patient support information, contacting relevant services and letting the patient know that you have done this.

Contact the council to arrange emergency housing for the family is incorrect - it breaks confidentiality as only relevant groups (e.g. child protection services) should be informed of the allegations. It is not your place to arrange housing for the family, especially without asking what the patient needs or wants. Your job is to inform appropriate services who will then help the patient make a plan.

Encourage the patient to arrange relationship counselling is incorrect. This does not deal with the risk to the patient or her children. It is not your place to make this suggestion and it is unlikely to be helpful in the context of domestic abuse.

Make the patient an appointment with a senior for the following week to discuss these concerns in greater detail and make a plan is incorrect as this involves not dealing with the disclosure or the risk to the children in a timely manner and may be seen as dismissive. Whilst it is likely you would want senior support in this case, the patient and her children still need to be dealt with immediately to keep them safe.

Reassure the patient that this information will be kept confidential but make her an appointment with a senior for the following day is incorrect. You need to act on the possible risk to the children immediately. Whilst the partner is meant to be away for the week, you cannot guarantee that he will not come home early and put the family at risk. It would be unacceptable to be aware of the risk to the family and not act until the following day. Whilst it would certainly be appropriate to seek senior support, this must be done immediately. Furthermore, it is not appropriate to tell the patient that the information will be kept confidential; as children are at risk, child protection services need to be aware, and the patient needs to know this. She is likely to lose her trust in you if you falsely tell her that no one else will be told of her allegations.

title: GMC: Protecting children and young people - Confidentiality and sharing information
body:
Patient confidentiality is crucial for building and maintaining trust and is therefore essential to the patient-doctor relationship. There are times, however, when it is necessary to break confidentiality, particularly where there are children involved.

Doctors are required to inform a relevant agency (such as the police or social services) where there is concern that a child or young person is currently suffering abuse or neglect, or is at risk of suffering abuse or neglect. This concern may arise from a consultation with the child or young person themselves, or a consultation with someone close to them.

This guidance about breaking confidentiality is different to that regarding adults. For example, if a woman presents to the surgery and makes a disclosure of domestic violence, the doctor is not required to inform local services if the patient does not wish them to. However, if there are children in the home and the patient suggests that her partner is also violent towards the children, a local agency must be informed.

Wherever possible, consent to disclose the relevant information should be obtained from the patient. This should involve explaining the following:
  • what information will be shared
  • who it will be shared with
  • how the information will be used
  • who they can go to for independent advice and support

However, consent should not be sought if this may put the child at greater risk and disclosure of information should not be delayed whilst consent is sought.

When informing an appropriate agency about concerns, the following information should be provided:
  • the identities of the child or young person, their parents and any other people that may pose a risk to them
  • the reasons for your concerns, including any relevant information about the child's health and any relevant information about the parents or carers

Doctors should always follow up their concerns and escalate to the next level of authority if they believe that the concerns are not being addressed appropriately.

Example 1

A 28-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner with facial swelling and bruising. On questioning, she reveals that her partner kicked her in the face during an argument. She states that he has also been aggressive to her two young children, once threatening her 3-year-old son with a knife. However, she begs you not to inform the police or social services, as she says she has the situation under control.

Explanation: In this situation, the general practitioner must inform social services immediately, or contact the police if they believe the children to be at risk of immediate harm. During the consultation, the GP should discuss with the patient what information they will be sharing, who they will be sharing it with and how the information will be used (ie what is likely to be the outcome of sharing this information). The doctor should also share the contact information for a local domestic abuse charity with the patient so that she can seek immediate advice and support if she wishes.

Example 2

The scenario is the same as above, except the patient threatens to move both the children and her abusive partner to her sister's home in France if the general practitioner informs social services or the police.

Explanation: In this scenario, it would be dangerous to inform the patient that you will be passing information onto the relevant agencies, as this would endanger the children. Therefore, the GP should immediately inform social services and/or the police without first informing the mother.
